      86. 86
        Schmidt, T. C.; Welker, A.; Rieger, M.; Sahu, P. K.; Sotriffer, C. A.; Schirmeister, T.; Engels, B. Protocol for Rational Design of Covalently Interacting Inhibitors. ChemPhysChem 2014, 15, 3226– 3235,  DOI: 10.1002/cphc.201402542
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        86
        Protocol for Rational Design of Covalently Interacting Inhibitors
        Schmidt, Thomas C.; Welker, Armin; Rieger, Max; Sahu, Prabhat K.; Sotriffer, Christoph A.; Schirmeister, Tanja; Engels, Bernd
        ChemPhysChem (2014), 15 (15), 3226-3235CODEN: CPCHFT; ISSN:1439-4235. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The inhibition potencies of covalent inhibitors mainly result from the formation of a covalent bond to the enzyme during the inhibition mechanism. This class of inhibitors has essentially been ignored in previous target-directed drug discovery projects because of concerns about possible side effects. However, their advantages, such as higher binding energies and longer drug-target residence times moved them into the focus of recent investigations. While the rational design of non-covalent inhibitors became std. the corresponding design of covalent inhibitors is still in its early stages. Potent covalent inhibitors can be retrieved from large compd. libraries by covalent docking approaches but protocols are missing that can reliably predict the influence of variations in the substitution pattern on the affinity and/or reactivity of a given covalent inhibitor. Hence, the wanted property profile can only be obtained from trial-and-error proceedings. This paper presents an appropriate protocol which is able to predict improved covalent inhibitors. It uses hybrid approaches, which mix quantum mech. (QM) and mol. mech. (MM) methods to predict variations in the reactivity of the inhibitor. They are also used to compute the required information about the non-covalent enzyme-inhibitor complex. Docking tools are employed to improve the inhibitor with respect to the non-covalent interactions formed in the binding site.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslCisLnP&md5=8d5389e92ef83e2d7f90c48a4bea5103
      87. 87
        Pinkas, D. M.; Strop, P.; Brunger, A. T.; Khosla, C. Transglutaminase 2 Undergoes a Large Conformational Change Upon Activation. PLoS Biol. 2007, 5, 2788– 2796,  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pbio.0050327
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      88. 88
        Badarau, E.; Wang, Z.; Rathbone, D. L.; Costanzi, A.; Thibault, T.; Murdoch, C. E.; El Alaoui, S.; Bartkeviciute, M.; Griffin, M. Development of Potent and Selective Tissue Transglutaminase Inhibitors: Their Effect on TG2 Function and Application in Pathological Conditions. Chem. Biol. 2015, 22, 1347– 1361,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chembiol.2015.08.013
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        88
        Development of Potent and Selective Tissue Transglutaminase Inhibitors: Their Effect on TG2 Function and Application in Pathological Conditions
        Badarau, Eduard; Wang, Zhuo; Rathbone, Dan L.; Costanzi, Andrea; Thibault, Thomas; Murdoch, Colin E.; El Alaoui, Said; Barkeviciute, Milda; Griffin, Martin
        Chemistry & Biology (Oxford, United Kingdom) (2015), 22 (10), 1347-1361CODEN: CBOLE2; ISSN:1074-5521. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Potent-selective peptidomimetic inhibitors of tissue transglutaminase (TG2) were developed through a combination of protein-ligand docking and mol. dynamic techniques. Derivs. of these inhibitors were made with the aim of specific TG2 targeting to the intra- and extracellular space. A cell-permeable fluorescently labeled deriv. enabled detection of in situ cellular TG2 activity in human umbilical cord endothelial cells and TG2-transduced NIH3T3 cells, which could be enhanced by treatment of cells with ionomycin. Reaction of TG2 with this fluorescent inhibitor in NIH3T3 cells resulted in loss of binding of TG2 to cell surface syndecan-4 and inhibition of translocation of the enzyme into the extracellular matrix, with a parallel redn. in fibronectin deposition. In human umbilical cord endothelial cells, this same fluorescent inhibitor also demonstrated a redn. in fibronectin deposition, cell motility, and cord formation in Matrigel. Use of the same inhibitor in a mouse model of hypertensive nephrosclerosis showed over a 40% redn. in collagen deposition.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhs1ertr7I&md5=a285a1e0aa9d391d8c0fe9be75e67144
      89. 89
        Atkovska, K.; Samsonov, S. A.; Paszkowski-Rogacz, M.; Pisabarro, M. T. Multipose Binding in Molecular Docking. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2014, 15, 2622– 2645,  DOI: 10.3390/ijms15022622
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        89
        Multipose binding in molecular docking
        Atkovska, Kalina; Samsonov, Sergey A.; Paszkowski-Rogacz, Maciej; Pisabarro, M. Teresa
        International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2014), 15 (2), 2622-2645, 24 pp.CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
        Mol. docking has been extensively applied in virtual screening of small mol. libraries for lead identification and optimization. A necessary prerequisite for successful differentiation between active and non-active ligands is the accurate prediction of their binding affinities in the complex by use of docking scoring functions. However, many studies have shown rather poor correlations between docking scores and exptl. binding affinities. Our work aimed to improve this correlation by implementing a multipose binding concept in the docking scoring scheme. Multipose binding, i.e., the property of certain protein-ligand complexes to exhibit different ligand binding modes, has been shown to occur in nature for a variety of mols. We conducted a high-throughput docking study and implemented multipose binding in the scoring procedure by considering multiple docking solns. in binding affinity prediction. In general, improvement of the agreement between docking scores and exptl. data was obsd., and this was most pronounced in complexes with large and flexible ligands and high binding affinities. Further developments of the selection criteria for docking solns. for each individual complex are still necessary for a general utilization of the multipose binding concept for accurate binding affinity prediction by mol. docking.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXptVWrs70%253D&md5=cfaafddb7f82d198a14b36e412c420c1

        Schrödinger Release; Maestro, Schrödinger; LLC, New York, NY, 2015-2016.

      91. 91
        Romoff, T. T.; Goodman, M. Urethane-Protected N-Carboxyanhydrides (UNCAS) as Unique Reactants for the Study of Intrinsic Racemization Tendencies in Peptide Synthesis. J. Pept. Res. 1997, 49, 281– 292,  DOI: 10.1111/j.1399-3011.1997.tb01128.x
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        91
        Urethane-protected N-carboxyanhydrides (UNCAs) as unique reactants for the study of intrinsic racemization tendencies in peptide synthesis
        Romoff, Todd T.; Goodman, Murray
        Journal of Peptide Research (1997), 49 (4), 281-292CODEN: JPERFA; ISSN:1397-002X. (Munksgaard)
        Urethane-protected N-carboxyanhydrides (UNCAs) are uniquely suited for the study of intrinsic racemization tendencies in peptide synthesis. The UNCA allows epimerization only by the direct enolization pathway (proton abstraction from the α-carbon) and does not decomp. upon epimerization. A protocol employing the quant. sepn. and anal. of enantiomeric N-protected amino acid derivs. by chiral HPLC has been developed to measure the intrinsic rate of racemization of UNCAs under widely varying reaction conditions. The influence of the tertiary amine structure, UNCA side chain structure, and solvent were studied. The same protocol was employed to study the intrinsic rate of racemization of N-protected activated amino acid intermediates generated via "onium-type" activating reagents. We have shown that the trends influencing the intrinsic rate of racemization of UNCAs are maintained under the conditions of in situ activations, and are consistent with the trends found in classical studies in the literature. The results are relevant to peptide synthesis both in soln. and on solid phase. The intrinsic rate of racemization for any type of activation with any tertiary amine can be measured by this protocol.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXjsVGks70%253D&md5=0e89541c5bd97a9aeee8cc594597cd1c

        Chung, S. I.; Shrager, R. I.; Folk, J. E. Mechanism of Action of Guinea Pig Liver Transglutaminase. VII. Chemical and Stereochemical Aspects of Substrate Binding and Catalysis. J. Biol. Chem. 1970, 245, 6424– 6435

      93. 93
        Taft, R. W. Linear Free Energy Relationships from Rates of Esterification and Hydrolysis of Aliphatic and Ortho-Substituted Benzoate Esters. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1952, 74, 2729– 2732,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01131a010
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        93
        Linear free-energy relationships from rates of esterification and hydrolysis of aliphatic and ortho-substituted benzoate esters
        Taft, Robert W., Jr.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1952), 74 (), 2729-32CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The existence of approx. linear free-energy relations between rates of esterification and hydrolysis for esters that do not follow the Hammett equation (Phys. Org. Chem., 1940, pp. 184-90, 222 (C.A. 34, 4332.7)) is reported. The reactivity of o-monosubstituted benzoate and aliph. esters toward esterification and hydrolysis can be described approx. by the equation, log(k/k0) = fA, where f is a proportionality const. dependent only on the nature of the reaction series; k is the rate const. for any ester (or acid) in a given reaction series; k0 is the rate const. for acetate or Et ester in a given aliph. reaction series, or for o-substituted benzoates it is the rate const. for o-toluate ester (or acid) in a given reaction series; A is a substituent const. dependent only on the nature of the substituent introduced. The equation is limited to esterification and hydrolysis reactions. The const. A for o-substituted benzoate or aliph. esters depends on whether the reaction is catalyzed by acid or base, and on whether structure is varied in the acyl or alkyl component of the ester. Values of A bear no apparent relation to the English-school theory of polarity of substituent groups. The equation fails to apply to both rate and equil. No variation greater than 20% occurs in f for solvents ranging from pure water to pure alcs. Changes in the structure of the acyl and alkyl components cause large and small variations, resp., in f. For acid catalysis f is practically the same for esterification as for hydrolysis. For base catalysis of the o-substituted benzoates, f appears to be essentially the same for hydrolysis and esterification.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG38Xls1CnsQ%253D%253D&md5=f4edd81b6727cf7704ca158be0d6f8a3
      94. 94
        Taft, R. W. Polar and Steric Substituent Constants for Aliphatic and O-Benzoate Groups from Rates of Esterification and Hydrolysis of Esters. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1952, 74, 3120– 3128,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01132a049
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        94
        Polar and steric substituent constants for aliphatic and o-benzoate groups from rates of esterification and hydrolysis of esters
        Taft, Robert W., Jr.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1952), 74 (), 3120-8CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        cf. C.A. 46, 9394h. Parameters Eσ and Es, which give nearly quant. measures of the polarities and steric factors, resp., assocd. with a large no. of aliph. and o-benzoate substituents are detd. from published rates of esterification and hydrolysis of esters. The equation (I) used to evaluate Eσ is (log k/k0)B - (log k/k0)A = Eσ(ρB - ρA), where Eσ is a substituent electron displacement (polarity) const., ρ is a reactions const. measuring the susceptibility of the given reaction series to polar substituents, k/k0 is the relative rate of hydrolysis or esterification for a substituent of an o-substituted benzoate or aliph. ester reaction series, and subscripts A and B refer to identical acid- and base-catalyzed reaction series, resp. The basic idea involved in I was suggested by Ingold (C.A. 24, 3990). The equation (II) used to evaluate Es is log k/k0 = Es + Eσρ, where Es is a substituent const. which depends on the gross steric effect of a substituent. Evidence indicates that steric factors assocd. with a given substituent are the same in identical acid- and base-catalyzed reaction series, so that I follows directly from II. As a first approxn., the relative rates of acid-catalyzed hydrolysis or esterification are detd. by steric factors alone, while for base-catalyzed reactions both polar and steric factors are involved. For o-substituted benzoates, Eσ values are essentially equal to Hammett σ values for corresponding p-substituents. For aliph. substituents, Eσ values are in accord with the qual. English-school theory of the polarity of groups. Corresponding Es values in acyl and alkyl components of esters are quant. parallel. The order of decreasing Es values is that of increasing steric requirements. Es values are not parallel in the acyl and alkyl components. Es and Eσ values are applied to other reactions; the logs of the relative rates of acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of o-substituted benzamides in H2O at 100° quant. parallel Es values; the logs of the relative rates of hydrolysis of a series of CH2O acetals and the logs of the relative ionization consts. of o-substituted benzoic acids in H2O at 25° quant. parallel corresponding Eσ values. For aliph. carboxylic acids such a parallelism is only qual. in general.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG38XmsVyiuw%253D%253D&md5=86e867cb556a1a1831331789264a1d2e
      95. 95
        Taft, R. W. Linear Steric Energy Relationships. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1953, 75, 4538– 4539,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01114a044
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        95
        Linear steric energy relationships
        Taft, Robert W., Jr.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1953), 75 (), 4538-9CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The rates for a limited no. of reaction series in which the polar effects of the substituents are small follow with fair precision the equation log k/k0 = δΕ8, where Ε8 is a steric substituent const. obtained from the rates of ester hydrolysis and esterification (cf. preceding abstr.), δ is a reaction const. giving the susceptibility of a reaction series to steric effects, and k/k0 is the relative rate of the acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of ortho substituted benzamides in water at 100°. The relative heats of reaction or activation for 2 reaction series fit the relation ΔH (or ΔΔH‡) = δΕ8. The steric susceptibility const. δ, the probable error of the fit of a single observation r, and the substituents (R) fitting the correlation were calcd. (given in the indicated order) for the following reaction series: acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of ο-RC6H4CONH2 in H2O at 100°, 0.812 ± 0.032, 0.05, MeO, EtO, Cl, Me, Br, I, and NO2; acid-catalyzed methanolysis of 2-naphthyl esters, 2-C10H7O2CR, in MeOH at 25°, 1.376 ± 0.057, 0.07, Me, Et, Pr, iso-Pr, Bu, and tert-Bu; acid-catalyzed alcoholysis with PrOH of 2-C10H7O2CR at 25°, 1.704 ± 0.093, 0.11, Me, Et, Pr, iso-Pr, Bu, and tert-Bu; acid-catalyzed alcoholysis of 2-C10H7O2CR with iso-PrOH at 25°, 1.882 ± 0.106, 0.13, Me, Et, Pr, iso-Pr, Bu, and tert-Bu; reaction of MeI with 2-alkylpyridines in PhNO2 at 30°, 2.065 ± 0.096, Me, Et, iso-Pr, and tert-Bu (all calcd. by the 1st equation). Similarly, the same values from the 2nd equation for the following reactions were calcd.: MeI with 2-alkylpyridines in PhNO2 (activation energy), 2.235 ± 0.089, 0.11, Me, Et, iso-Pr, and tert-Bu; and 2-alkylpyridines with BF3 in PhNO2 (heat of reaction), 5.4g ± 0.36, 0.45, Me, Et, iso-Pr, and tert-Bu. All of the values obtained are pos.; this indicates that in each case the steric requirements of the substituents are greater in the transition or final state than in the initial one.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Steric effects. 7. Additional V constants
        Charton, Marvin
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1976), 41 (12), 2217-20CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263.
        From correlations of rate constants for esterification or acid-catalyzed hydrolysis with the modified Taft equation, log kX = ψυX + h, new υ constants for 93 substituents were detd. On the basis of these υ constants and the 61 υ values previously available, the variation of υ with structure is discussed.

        97
        Steric effects. I. Esterification and acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of esters
        Charton, Marvin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1975), 97 (6), 1552-6CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        A steric parameter (ν), obtained from van der Waals radii, was used to correlate rate consts. for acid-catalyzed esterification, hydrolysis, and alcoholysis. The ν values of 61 groups were reported. The Es parameters of Taft, Hancock, and Palm were criticized. The rates of acid-catalyzed esterification were solely a function of steric effects.

      105. 105
        Malik, N.; Solbach, C.; Voelter, W.; Machulla, H.-J. Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution by [18F]Fluoride at Substituted 2-Nitropyridines. J. Radioanal. Nucl. Chem. 2010, 283, 757– 764,  DOI: 10.1007/s10967-009-0410-2
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        105
        Nucleophilic aromatic substitution by [18F]fluoride at substituted 2-nitropyridines
        Malik, Noeen; Solbach, Christoph; Voelter, Wolfgang; Machulla, Hans-Juergen
        Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry (2010), 283 (3), 757-764CODEN: JRNCDM; ISSN:0236-5731. (Springer)
        For the radiofluorination of benzenes and benzene derivs., the electrophilic reaction with [18F]F2 is a very common route. Yet, arom. nucleophilic substitution (SNAr) by n.c.a [18F]fluoride, which can be produced efficiently in high amts., has been considered to be very desirable. However, to facilitate 18F-labeling via SNAr at an electron rich arom. system, an appropriate leaving group must be present together with an auxiliary group in ortho or para position to the leaving group. An interesting alternative for the auxiliary group is the heteroatom of a heteroarom. system, for which pyridine is a leading example. Dolci et al. (J Label Compd Radiopharm 42:975-985, 1999) have evaluated the scope of the nucleophilic arom. fluorination of 2-substituted pyridine rings using the activated K [18F]F-K222 complex. As Me and methoxy groups are known to enhance the electron d. of an arom. system by the +I and the +M effect, resp., SNAr is unlikely to occur. Until now, the effect of these substituents has not been studied towards the 18F-radiofluorination of substituted 2-nitropyridines by use of [18F]fluoride. Therefore, we have investigated the effect of methoxy and Me groups in 2-nitropyridines. The results showed that 3-methoxy-2-nitropyridine and 3-methyl-2-nitropyridine can efficiently be substituted by [18F]fluoride with high RCY's (70-89%) in short reaction times (1-30 min) at a reaction temp. of 140 °C. Moreover, 3-methoxy-6-methyl-2-[18F]fluoropyridine was obtained from the corresponding nitro-precursor in a high yield of 81 ± 1% after 30 min at 140 °C. In case of 2-nitropyridines data indicates the effect of Me and methoxy groups on SNAr to be of minor importance.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhs1arsrg%253D&md5=481b3d70b1acfa490ea01758a15eedc0
      106. 106
        Dolci, L.; Dolle, F.; Jubeau, S.; Vaufrey, F.; Crouzel, C. 2-[18F]Fluoropyridines by No-Carrier-Added Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution with [18F]FK-K222—a Comparative Study. J. Labelled Compd. Radiopharm. 1999, 42, 975– 985,  DOI: 10.1002/(SICI)1099-1344(199910)42:10<975::AID-JLCR256>3.0.CO;2-E
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        106
        2-[18F]fluoropyridines by no-carrier-added nucleophilic aromatic substitution with [18F]FK-K222 - a comparative study
        Dolci, Lilian; Dolle, Frederic; Jubeau, Sebastien; Vaufrey, Francoise; Crouzel, Christian
        Journal of Labelled Compounds & Radiopharmaceuticals (1999), 42 (10), 975-985CODEN: JLCRD4; ISSN:0362-4803. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        The scope of the nucleophilic arom. substitution reaction of 2-substituted pyridines with no-carrier-added [18F]fluoride ion (half life: 110 min) as its [18F]FK-K222 activated complex, was evaluated via the radiosynthesis of 2-[18F]fluoropyridine, chosen as a model reaction. The parameters studied include the influence of the leaving group in the 2 position of the pyridine ring, the quantity of the precursor used, the type of activation (conventional heating, micro- & ultrasonic wave irradiations), the solvent, the temp. and the duration of the reaction. Concerning the influence of the leaving group, 2-chloro- and 2-bromopyridine gave moderate to good fluorine-18 incorporation yields while 2-nitro- and esp. 2-trimethylammonium pyridine gave excellent incorporation yields. Noteworthy, 2-iodopyridine was almost un-reactive. As expected, the incorporation yield increased with the quantity of precursor used: high yields were obsd. from about 7 μmol of precursor. Using conventional heating and regardless of the substituent in the 2 position of the pyridine ring, the best yields for the radiosynthesis of 2-[18F]fluoropyridine were obtained when the temp. of the reaction was 180°C and the solvent DMSO. The yields for the 2-nitro- and the 2-trimethylammonium pyridine precursors were 77% and 88% resp., after only 5 min of reaction and were similar to those obsd. at 150°C for longer reaction times. At 120°C, neither the 2-chloro- nor the 2-bromopyridine gave any incorporation. Using microwave irradiations, excellent incorporation yields (96%) were obsd. for the 2-trimethylammonium pyridine from 1 min of reaction at 100 W in DMSO. Concerning the 2-chloro-, 2-bromo- and 2-nitropyridine, the use of 100 W microwave irradiations for 2 min gave yields comparable to those obtained for 10 min of conventional heating at 180°C, 22%, 71% and 88% resp. No incorporation at all of the radioactivity could be detected when ultrasonic waves were applied, even with long reaction time and high power.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXms1ahs7s%253D&md5=0ba3892da304b1a8754eedc3f5b338c7

        108
        A Medicinal Chemist's Guide to Molecular Interactions
        Bissantz, Caterina; Kuhn, Bernd; Stahl, Martin
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 53 (14), 5061-5084CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A review.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjvFKjtbs%253D&md5=f39cf8700267cdc311c73de4d433bab0
      109. 109
        Persch, E.; Dumele, O.; Diederich, F. Molecular Recognition in Chemical and Biological Systems. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2015, 54, 3290– 3327,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201408487
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        109
        Molecular Recognition in Chemical and Biological Systems
        Persch, Elke; Dumele, Oliver; Diederich, Francois
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (11), 3290-3327CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Structure-based ligand design in medicinal chem. and crop protection relies on the identification and quantification of weak noncovalent interactions and understanding the role of water. Small-mol. and protein structural database searches are important tools to retrieve existing knowledge. Thermodn. profiling, combined with x-ray structural and computational studies, is the key to elucidate the energetics of the replacement of water by ligands. Biol. receptor sites vary greatly in shape, conformational dynamics, and polarity, and require different ligand-design strategies, as shown for various case studies. Interactions between dipoles have become a central theme of mol. recognition. Orthogonal interactions, halogen bonding, and amide···π stacking provide new tools for innovative lead optimization. The combination of synthetic models and biol. complexation studies is required to gather reliable information on weak noncovalent interactions and the role of water.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjslCitbY%253D&md5=6cc7102842c1e16e4a64352214f038b7
      110. 110
        Klebe, G. Applying Thermodynamic Profiling in Lead Finding and Optimization. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2015, 14, 95– 110,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd4486
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        110
        Applying thermodynamic profiling in lead finding and optimization
        Klebe, Gerhard
        Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2015), 14 (2), 95-110CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Small-mol. drug discovery involves the optimization of various physicochem. properties of a ligand, particularly its binding affinity for its target receptor (or receptors). In recent years, there has been growing interest in using thermodn. profiling of ligand-receptor interactions in order to select and optimize those ligands that might be most likely to become drug candidates with desirable physicochem. properties. The thermodn. of binding is influenced by multiple factors, including hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic interactions, desolvation, residual mobility, dynamics and the local water structure. This article discusses key issues in understanding the effects of these factors and applying this knowledge in drug discovery.

        116
        The pKBHX Database: Toward a Better Understanding of Hydrogen-Bond Basicity for Medicinal Chemists
        Laurence, Christian; Brameld, Ken A.; Graton, Jerome; Le Questel, Jean-Yves; Renault, Eric
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 52 (14), 4073-4086CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The pKBHX database is presented, which corresponds to three main fields of data: hydrogen bond donor identification, thermodn. data and spectroscopic data. The pKBHX scale of hydrogen donor basicity differs considerable from the pKBH+ scale of proton transfer basicity. The hydrogen bond basicities of functional groups relevant to medicinal chem. and drug design is reviewed.

      117. 117
        Hammett, L. P. The Effect of Structure Upon the Reactions of Organic Compounds Benzene Derivatives. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1937, 59, 96– 103,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01280a022
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        117
        Effect of structure upon the reactions of organic compounds. Benzene derivatives
        Hammett, Louis P.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1937), 59 (), 96-103CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        A simple formula is proposed to represent the effect of a substituent in the m- or p- position of the benzene ring upon the rate or equil. of a reaction in which the reacting group is in a side chain attached to the ring. This formula represents the total effect of the substituent and also the influence of changing length of the side chain, of the dielec. const. of the medium, and of temp. with a satisfactory precision in a wide variety of cases. The theory that a substituent acts by internal electron displacement is in complete agreement with this and accounts also for the large deviations observed in the case of nonrigid structures. Tables of substituent and reaction consts. are given from which the effect of many substituents upon a large no. of reaction rates and equil may be obtained.

        Baitinger, W. F.; Robinson, L.; Schleyer, P. V.; Murty, T. S. S. Nitro Groups as Proton Acceptors in Hydrogen Bonding. Tetrahedron 1964, 20, 1635– 1647,  DOI: 10.1016/S0040-4020(01)99161-6
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        121
        Nitro groups as proton acceptors in hydrogen bonding
        Baitinger, W. F.; Schleyer, P. von R.; Murty, T. S. S. R.; Robinson, L.
        Tetrahedron (1964), 20 (7), 1635-47CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020.
        Intermol. H bonding of MeOH and PhOH to a variety of NO2 compds. was studied in CCl4 soln. by infrared spectroscopy and tabulated results established conclusively that the NO2 group can act as a proton acceptor. Spectra of β-nitro alcs. in CCl4 provided incontrovertible evidence that intramol. H bonding was present, contrary to recent literature reports. Spectral shifts of OH proton donors bonding to nitro compds. are small, indicating the weakly basic character of the NO2 function. The magnitude of intermol. spectral shifts to nitro compds. depends markedly on proton acceptor concn. and the desirability of making such measurements by extrapolation to infinite diln. was emphasized. The data revealed appreciable ground state resonance interaction between NO2 groups and aromatic rings in PhNO2 and its derivs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF2cXktl2qtL4%253D&md5=51dbcb4414896dd163b6bfd76c788e14

        Tan, C. M.; Chen, G. S.; Chen, C. S.; Chang, P. T.; Chern, J. W. Chem. 2011, 19, 6316– 6328,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2011.09.003

        122
        Design, synthesis and biological evaluation of benzo[1.3.2]dithiazolium ylide 1,1-dioxide derivatives as potential dual cyclooxygenase-2/5-lipoxygenase inhibitors
        Tan, Chen-Ming; Chen, Grace Shiahuy; Chen, Chien-Shu; Chang, Pei-Teh; Chern, Ji-Wang
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2011), 19 (21), 6316-6328CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
        3-(4-Bromophenyl)-6-nitrobenzo[1.3.2]dithiazolium ylide 1,1-dioxide [I (R = Br)] was discovered as a new prototype for dual inhibitors of cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) and 5-lipoxygenase (5-LOX). Thus, the structure-activity relationships of benzo[1.3.2]dithiazolium ylide 1,1-dioxide skeleton were carried out. The 6-NO2 group played an essential role in the inhibitory activity. In addn., moderate-sized lipophilic substituents at the para-position of the 3-aryl moiety were required for dual COX-2/5-LOX inhibitory activity. Among the identified potent dual inhibitors, 3-(4-tbutylphenyl) deriv. I [R = t-Bu] (II)(IC50 values of 0.27 μM and 0.30 μM against COX-2 and 5-LOX, resp.) and 3-(4-biphenyl) deriv. I [R = Ph] (IC50 values of 0.50 μM and 0.15 μM against COX-2 and 5-LOX, resp.) were the most potent dual COX-2/5-LOX inhibitors. I.p. administration of II at 100 mg/kg demonstrated potent acute anti-inflammatory activity. As a result, benzo[1.3.2]dithiazolium ylide 1,1-dioxide represented a novel scaffold for the exploitation in developing dual COX-2/5-LOX inhibitors.

        Module-assisted synthesis of the bifunctional labelling agent N-succinimidyl 4-[(18)F]fluorobenzoate ([(18)F]SFB)
        Mading P; Fuchtner F; Wust F
        Applied radiation and isotopes : including data, instrumentation and methods for use in agriculture, industry and medicine (2005), 63 (3), 329-32 ISSN:0969-8043.
        The three-step radiosynthesis of N-succinimidyl 4-[(18)F]fluorobenzoate ([(18)F]SFB) was adapted to a remotely controlled synthesis module. After optimization of the reaction conditions, the final [(18)F]SFB was obtained in decay-corrected radiochemical yields of 34-38% (related to [(18)F]fluoride; n=12) within a synthesis time of 68 min. The radiochemical purity was in the range of 93-96%.

        Wenzel, B.; Hiller, A.; Fischer, S.; Sorger, D.; Deuther-Conrad, W.; Scheunemann, M.; Brust, P.; Sabri, O.; Steinbach, J. In Vitro Binding Profile and Radiosynthesis of a Novel 18F-Labeled Azaspirovesamicol Analog as Potential Ligand for Imaging of the Vesicular Acetylcholine Transporter. J. Labelled Compd. Radiopharm. 2011, 54, 426– 432,  DOI: 10.1002/jlcr.1891
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        127
        In vitro binding profile and radiosynthesis of a novel 18F-labeled azaspirovesamicol analog as potential ligand for imaging of the vesicular acetylcholine transporter
        Wenzel, Barbara; Hiller, Achim; Fischer, Steffen; Sorger, Dietlind; Deuther-Conrad, Winnie; Scheunemann, Matthias; Brust, Peter; Sabri, Osama; Steinbach, Joerg
        Journal of Labelled Compounds and Radiopharmaceuticals (2011), 54 (8), 426-432CODEN: JLCRD4; ISSN:0362-4803. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        Radiolabeled vesamicol analogs are promising candidates as ligands for the vesicular acetylcholine transporter (VAChT) to enable in vivo imaging of early cholinergic degenerations in brain. The 4-fluorobenzoyl-substituted azaspirovesamicol deriv. FBASV is one out of six novel vesamicol analogs and demonstrated most appropriate in vitro binding data. 18F-radiolabeling was performed by microwave-assisted nucleophilic arom. substitution of the corresponding nitro precursor and two methods were developed for the purifn. of [18F]FBASV. Utilizing method A, the remaining nitro precursor was reduced to its corresponding amine, which was sepd. via semi-preparative HPLC on a conventional RP column. In method B a Ph column was used for the direct sepn. of [18F]FBASV and its nitro precursor, resulting in a change of the elution order and better sepn. parameters. Thus, [18F]FBASV was synthesized with a RCY of 16-18%, a specific activity >300 GBq/μmol, and a radiochem. purity of >99.5% suitable for future in vivo studies. Copyright © 2011 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXptVehtr8%253D&md5=c951fecdf4e526e8d7996427a605791f
      128. 128
        Choi, K.; Siegel, M.; Piper, J. L.; Yuan, L.; Cho, E.; Strnad, P.; Omary, B.; Rich, K. M.; Khosla, C. Chemistry and Biology of Dihydroisoxazole Derivatives: Selective Inhibitors of Human Transglutaminase 2. Chem. Biol. 2005, 12, 469– 475,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chembiol.2005.02.007
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        128
        Chemistry and Biology of Dihydroisoxazole Derivatives: Selective Inhibitors of Human Transglutaminase 2
        Choi, Kihang; Siegel, Matthew; Piper, Justin L.; Yuan, Liya; Cho, Eun; Strnad, Pavel; Omary, Bishr; Rich, Keith M.; Khosla, Chaitan
        Chemistry & Biology (2005), 12 (4), 469-475CODEN: CBOLE2; ISSN:1074-5521. (Cell Press)
        Summary: 3-Halo-4,5-dihydroisoxazoles are attractive warheads for the selective inhibition of nucleophilic active sites in biol. systems. A series of 3-bromo-4,5-dihydroisoxazole compds. were prepd. and tested for their ability to irreversibly inhibit human transglutaminase 2 (TG2), an enzyme that plays an important role in the pathogenesis of diverse disorders including Celiac Sprue and certain types of cancers. Several compds. showed high specificity for human TG2 (kinh/KI > 2000 min-1M-1) but essentially no reactivity (k < 1 min-1M-1) toward physiol. thiols such as glutathione. The pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties of a prototype dihydroisoxazole inhibitor, 1b, were evaluated; in mice the compd. showed good oral bioavailability, short serum half-life and efficient TG2 inhibition in small intestinal tissue, and low toxicity. It also showed excellent synergism with N,N'-bis(2-chloroethyl)-N-nitrosourea (BCNU, carmustine) against refractory glioblastoma tumors in mice. A fluorescent dihydroisoxazole inhibitor 5 facilitated microscopic visualization of TG2 endocytosis from the extracellular surface of HCT-116 cells. Together, these findings demonstrate the promise of dihydroisoxazole compds. as probes for the biol. of TG2 and its role in human disease.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjsFKitb0%253D&md5=33734bc262ee1f253b76af4158369ec3

        Siebert, C. D. Das Bioisosterie-Konzept: Arzneistoffentwicklung. Chem. Unserer Zeit 2004, 38, 320– 324,  DOI: 10.1002/ciuz.200400331
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        129
        Drug development. The bioisosterism concept
        Siebert, CarsteSiebert, Carsten
        Chemie in Unserer Zeit (2004), 38 (5), 320-324CODEN: CUNZAW; ISSN:0009-2851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review on the concept of bioisosterism in drug research, including the replacement of substituents and atoms in pharmacol. active compds. The prominent couples benzene-thiophene, benzene-pyridine, thiophene-furan, and several other examples of bioisosterism in drug research are discussed. Selected drugs are shown to introduce into this important principle of rational drug design.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVeku7rE&md5=80a121abcdb1c54eb3c7abf30a56e437
      130. 130
        Meanwell, N. A. Synopsis of Some Recent Tactical Application of Bioisosteres in Drug Design. J. Med. Chem. 2011, 54, 2529– 2591,  DOI: 10.1021/jm1013693
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        130
        Synopsis of Some Recent Tactical Application of Bioisosteres in Drug Design
        Meanwell, Nicholas A.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2011), 54 (8), 2529-2591CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The established utility of bioisosteres is broad in nature, extending to improving potency, enhancing selectivity, altering phys. properties, reducing or redirecting metab., eliminating or modifying toxicophores, and acquiring novel intellectual property. In this Perspective, some contemporary themes exploring the role of isosteres in drug design are sampled, with an emphasis placed on tactical applications designed to solve the kinds of problems that impinge on compd. optimization and the long-term success of drug candidates. Interesting concepts that may have been poorly effective in the context examd. are captured, since the ideas may have merit in alternative circumstances. A comprehensive cataloging of bioisosteres is beyond the scope of what will be provided, although a synopsis of relevant isosteres of a particular functionality is summarized in a succinct fashion in several sections. Isosterism has also found productive application in the design and optimization of organocatalysts, and there are several examples in which functional mimicry established initially in a medicinal chem. setting has been adopted by this community.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjsVCnu7o%253D&md5=0637ab60c379bef535f3f709b26f3582

        Cametti, M.; Dalla Cort, A.; Mandolini, L. Substituent Effects in Cation−π Interactions. Recognition of Tetramethylammonium Chloride by Uranyl-Salophen Receptors. Chem. Sci. 2012, 3, 2119,  DOI: 10.1039/c2sc00675h

        Substituent effects in cation-π interactions. Recognition of tetramethylammonium chloride by uranyl-salophen receptors
        Cametti, Massimo; Dalla Cort, Antonella; Mandolini, Luigi
        Chemical Science (2012), 3 (6), 2119-2122CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The binding affinities of tetramethylammonium chloride to uranyl salophen receptors decorated with X-substituted arom. pendants (X = OCH3, CH3, H, Br, NO2) point to the importance of resonance effects in cation-π interactions, at variance with the view that field/inductive effects play a dominant role.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xnt12qt7o%253D&md5=4754c375841afc0884d44f576fcbad57
      134. 134
        Biedermann, F.; Schneider, H. J. Experimental Binding Energies in Supramolecular Complexes. Chem. Rev. 2016, 116, 5216– 5300,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.5b00583
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        134
        Experimental Binding Energies in Supramolecular Complexes
        Biedermann, Frank; Schneider, Hans-Joerg
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2016), 116 (9), 5216-5300CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        On the basis of many literature measurements, a crit. overview is given on essential noncovalent interactions in synthetic supramol. complexes, accompanied by analyses with selected proteins. The methods, which can be applied to derive binding increments for single noncovalent interactions, start with the evaluation of consistency and additivity with a sufficiently large no. of different host-guest complexes by applying linear free energy relations. Other strategies involve the use of double mutant cycles, of mol. balances, of dynamic combinatorial libraries, and of crystal structures. Promises and limitations of these strategies are discussed. Most of the analyses stem from soln. studies, but a few also from gas phase. The empirically derived interactions are then presented on the basis of selected complexes with respect to ion pairing, hydrogen bonding, electrostatic contributions, halogen bonding, π-π-stacking, dispersive forces, cation-π and anion-π interactions, and contributions from the hydrophobic effect. Cooperativity in host-guest complexes as well as in self-assembly, and entropy factors are briefly highlighted.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XntVSjsrg%253D&md5=4eb3ad9e9022df4e7600b60423352815

        Prime, M. E.; Andersen, O. A.; Barker, J. J.; Brooks, M. A.; Cheng, R. K.; Toogood-Johnson, I.; Courtney, S. M.; Brookfield, F. A.; Yarnold, C. J.; Marston, R. W.; Johnson, P. D.; Johnsen, S.         136
        Discovery and Structure-Activity Relationship of Potent and Selective Covalent Inhibitors of Transglutaminase 2 for Huntington's Disease
        Prime, Michael E.; Andersen, Ole A.; Barker, John J.; Brooks, Mark A.; Cheng, Robert K. Y.; Toogood-Johnson, Ian; Courtney, Stephen M.; Brookfield, Frederick A.; Yarnold, Christopher J.; Marston, Richard W.; Johnson, Peter D.; Johnsen, Siw F.; Palfrey, Jordan J.; Vaidya, Darshan; Erfan, Sayeh; Ichihara, Osamu; Felicetti, Brunella; Palan, Shilpa; Pedret-Dunn, Anna; Schaertl, Sabine; Sternberger, Ina; Ebneth, Andreas; Scheel, Andreas; Winkler, Dirk; Toledo-Sherman, Leticia; Beconi, Maria; Macdonald, Douglas; Munoz-Sanjuan, Ignacio; Dominguez, Celia; Wityak, John
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 55 (3), 1021-1046CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        Tissue transglutaminase 2 (TG2) is a multifunctional protein primarily known for its calcium-dependent enzymic protein crosslinking activity via iso-peptide bond formation between glutamine and lysine residues. TG2 overexpression and activity have been found to be assocd. with Huntington's disease (HD); specifically, TG2 is up-regulated in the brains of HD patients and in animal models of the disease. Interestingly, genetic deletion of TG2 in two different HD mouse models, R6/1 and R6/2, results in improved phenotypes including a redn. in neuronal death and prolonged survival. Starting with phenyl-acrylamide screening hit I, the SAR of this series leading to potent and selective TG2 inhibitors is described. The suitability of the compds. as in vitro tools to elucidate the biol. of TG2 was demonstrated through mode of inhibition studies, characterization of drug like properties, and inhibition profiles in a cell lysate assay.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XktVGqug%253D%253D&md5=59d1b7bd0253c0801dcbc0a184f978b5
      137. 137
        Avdeef, A. The Rise of PAMPA. Expert Opin. Drug Metab. Toxicol. 2005, 1, 325– 342,  DOI: 10.1517/17425255.1.2.325
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        137
        The rise of PAMPA
        Avdeef, Alex
        Expert Opinion on Drug Metabolism & Toxicology (2005), 1 (2), 325-342CODEN: EODMAP; ISSN:1742-5255. (Ashley Publications Ltd.)
        A review. The parallel artificial membrane permeability assay (PAMPA), as a passive-permeability screen, is a possible low-cost alternative to cellular models for the earliest ADME primary screening of research compds. Its popularity in the industry has risen rapidly. This review examines state-of-the-art PAMPA methods. The various covered topics include: different lipid formulations, the quant. relationships between hexadecane, dioyleyoylphosphatidycholine and Double-Sink PAMPA measurements, the use of individual-well stirring, issues of UV sensitivity, timing strategies, reproducibility of measurements, the correct pH to perform the measurement to avoid aq. boundary layer problems, the pKaflux method for detg. intrinsic permeability coeffs. and the cosolvent method for very insol. mols. Examples of the detn. of permeability of very difficult mols., but mols. that are well absorbed, are given. Carefully gathered evidence in support of the use of the Double-Sink PAMPA model is presented. The review concludes with a binning strategy to predict human intestinal absorption, based on the use of the sum of permeability coeffs., measured at gradient pH 5.0, 6.2 and 7.4. Opinions regarding the future of PAMPA are offered.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtVKltLfL&md5=8b5707019be881e64cf214db87722209

        Kansy, M.; Senner, F.; Gubernator, K. Physicochemical High Throughput Screening: Parallel Artificial Membrane Permeation Assay in the Description of Passive Absorption Processes. J. Med. Chem. 1998, 41, 1007– 1010,  DOI: 10.1021/jm970530e
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        139
        Physicochemical High Throughput Screening: Parallel Artificial Membrane Permeation Assay in the Description of Passive Absorption Processes
        Kansy, Manfred; Senner, Frank; Gubernator, Klaus
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1998), 41 (7), 1007-1010CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        The majority of pharmaceutical discovery projects aim for an orally available form of a new therapeutic principle. One obstacle for per oral treatment is intestinal absorption. A simple predictive exptl. method to assess the potential of intestinal absorption is therefore highly welcome. The authors describe here the PAMPA (Parallel Artificial Membrane Permeation Assay) method, a simple, robust, high throughput screen (HTS) which has been shown to be predictive for passive diffusion through membranes and thus for oral absorption. In addn. PAMPA can deliver information in parallel on the lipophilicity, the ionization state and the soly. of a compd. Therefore PAMPA complements HTS, combinatorial chem. and parallel synthesis efforts in preclin. pharmaceutical research.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXhs12kt70%253D&md5=85d8ab409313b583de52348eb4d895da
      140. 140
        Ruell, J. A.; Tsinman, K. L.; Avdeef, A. PAMPA—a Drug Absorption in Vitro Model 5. Unstirred Water Layer in Iso-pH Mapping Assays and pKaflux —Optimized Design (pOD-PAMPA). Eur. J. Pharm. Sci. 2003, 20, 393– 402,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejps.2003.08.006
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        140
        PAMPA-a drug absorption in vitro model 5. Unstirred water layer in iso-pH mapping assays and pKaflux-optimized design (pOD-PAMPA)
        Ruell, Jeffrey A.; Tsinman, Konstantin L.; Avdeef, Alex
        European Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences (2003), 20 (4-5), 393-402CODEN: EPSCED; ISSN:0928-0987. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Iso-pH mapping unstirred parallel artificial membrane permeability assay (PAMPA) was used to measure the effective permeability, Pe, as a function of pH from 3 to 10, of five weak monoprotic acids (ibuprofen, naproxen, ketoprofen, salicylic acid, benzoic acid), an ampholyte (piroxicam), five monoprotic weak bases (imipramine, verapamil, propranolol, phenazopyridine, metoprolol), and a diprotic weak base (quinine). The intrinsic permeability, Po, the unstirred water layer (UWL) permeability, Pu, and the apparent pKa (pKaflux) were detd. from the pH dependence of log Pe. The underlying permeability-pH equations were derived for multiprotic weak acids, weak bases and ampholytes. The av. thickness of the unstirred water layer on each side of the membrane was estd. to be nearly 2000 μm, somewhat larger than that found in Caco-2 permeability assays (unstirred). Since the UWL thickness in the human intestine is believed to be about forty times smaller, it is crit. to correct the in vitro permeability data for the effect of the UWL. Without such correction, the in vitro permeability coeff. of lipophilic mols. would be indicative only of the property of water. In single-pH PAMPA (e.g. pH 7.4), the uncertainty of the UWL contribution can be minimized if a specially-selected pH (possibly different from 7.4) were used in the assay. From the anal. of the shapes of the log Pe-pH plots, a method to improve the selection of the assay pH, called pKaflux-optimized design (pOD-PAMPA), was described and tested. From an optimally-selected assay pH, it is possible to est. Po, as well as the entire membrane permeability-pH profile.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXptlynurg%253D&md5=f8e48ffeec57c1c70d89ce1aead8b683
      141. 141
        Avdeef, A.; Strafford, M.; Block, E.; Balogh, M. P.; Chambliss, W.; Khan, I. Drug Absorption in Vitro Model: Filter-Immobilized Artificial Membranes. 2. Studies of the Permeability Properties of Lactones in Piper Methysticum Forst. Eur. J. Pharm. Sci. 2001, 14, 271– 280,  DOI: 10.1016/S0928-0987(01)00191-9
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        141
        Drug absorption in vitro model: filter-immobilized artificial membranes 2. Studies of the permeability properties of lactones in Piper methysticum Forst
        Avdeef, Alex; Strafford, Melissa; Block, Eric; Balogh, Michael P.; Chambliss, Walter; Khan, Ikhlas
        European Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences (2001), 14 (4), 271-280CODEN: EPSCED; ISSN:0928-0987. (Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.)
        The assessment of transport properties of 23 drug and natural product mols. was made using the in vitro model based on filter-immobilized artificial membranes (filter-IAM), assembled from phosphatidylcholine in dodecane, in buffer solns. at pH 7.4. Five of the compds. were lactones extd. from the roots of the kava-kava plant. Expts. were designed to test the effects of stirring (0-600 rpm) during assays and the effects of varying the assay times (2-15 h). The highly mobile kava lactones permeated in the order dihydromethisticin (40)>yangonin (37)>kavain (34)>methisticin (32)> desmethoxyyangonin (26), the nos. in parentheses being the measured effective permeabilities in units of 10-6 cm/s. By comparison, com. drugs ranked: phenazopyridine (35)>testosterone (19)>propranolol (13)>ketoconazole (6.3)>piroxicam (2.2)>caffeine (1.7)>metoprolol (0.8)>terbutaline (0.01). In addn. to permeability measurements, membrane retention of compds. was detd. Yangonin, desmethoxyyangonin, ketoconazole, and phenazopyridine were more than 60% retained by the artificial membranes contg. phospholipids. Stirring during assay significantly increased the obsd. permeabilities for highly mobile mols., but had minimal impact on the poorly permeable mols. The influence of hydrogen bonding was explored by detg. permeabilities using filters coated with dodecane free of phospholipids. In the filter-IAM method, concns. were detd. by plate microtiter UV spectrophotometry and by LC-MS. Higher-throughput was achieved with direct UV by the use of 96-well microtiter plate formats and with LC-MS by the use of cassette dosing (five-in-one).

      144. 144
        Korjamo, T.; Heikkinen, A. T.; Monkkonen, J. Analysis of Unstirred Water Layer in in Vitro Permeability Experiments. J. Pharm. Sci. 2009, 98, 4469– 4479,  DOI: 10.1002/jps.21762
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        145
        Analysis of unstirred water layer in in vitro permeability experiments
        Korjamo, Timo; Heikkinen, Aki T.; Moenkkoenen, Jukka
        Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences (2009), 98 (12), 4469-4479CODEN: JPMSAE; ISSN:0022-3549. (Wiley-Liss, Inc.)
        A review. In vitro permeability expts. are used widely in drug discovery and other areas of pharmaceutical research. Much effort has been expended in developing novel epithelial models but generally much less attention has been paid to the hydrodynamic barrier in the actual expts. The restricted liq. flow in the vicinity of solid surfaces leads to a zone where the diffusional movement of mols. exceeds the convection. This leads to formation of a concn. gradient between the bulk soln. and the surface. The formed unstirred water layer (UWL) reduces the apparent permeability (Papp) of compds. that rapidly pass through the actual epithelial layer. This lowers the resoln. of Papp vs. fraction-absorbed assay, complicates the structure-permeability anal. and skews apparent kinetic parameters of transporter substrates. This review describes the techniques that can be used to det. the UWL thickness in permeability expts. and apparatuses described in the literature to control the in vitro hydrodynamics. © 2009 Wiley-Liss, Inc. and the American Pharmacists Assocn. J Pharm Sci 98:4469-4479, 2009.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlCjsL7L&md5=5322b8665bd474a5b11bc3128a2831f2
      145. 145
        Sugano, K. Aqueous Boundary Layers Related to Oral Absorption of a Drug: From Dissolution of a Drug to Carrier Mediated Transport and Intestinal Wall Metabolism. Mol. Pharmaceutics 2010, 7, 1362– 1373,  DOI: 10.1021/mp1001119
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        146
        Aqueous Boundary Layers Related to Oral Absorption of a Drug: From Dissolution of a Drug to Carrier Mediated Transport and Intestinal Wall Metabolism
        Sugano, Kiyohiko
        Molecular Pharmaceutics (2010), 7 (5), 1362-1373CODEN: MPOHBP; ISSN:1543-8384. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The aq. boundary layer (ABL) affects various aspects of oral absorption of a drug, from dissoln. of the drug to the apparent Km value of intestinal wall metab. and carrier mediated transport. However, the importance of ABL has often been entirely ignored in oral absorption investigation. In this minireview, the effect of ABL on oral absorption of a drug is discussed in an easy-to-understand manner. This review starts with an introduction of the boundary layer theory with many illustrations (and links to public web movies visualizing the ABL), and then discusses some specific cases of interest in pharmaceutical science, such as dissoln. of floating drug particles in the USP paddle app. The effect of the boundary layer on the membrane permeation is also discussed from the viewpoint of structure permeability relationship, carrier mediated transport/metab. and estn. of the fraction of a dose absorbed for poor soly. compds.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpvVylur0%253D&md5=11414adf02991dab40bb54311a58b3e3

      147. 147
        Chen, I. J.; Taneja, R.; Yin, D.; Seo, P. R.; Young, D.; MacKerell, A. D.; Polli, J. E. Chemical Substituent Effect on Pyridine Permeability and Mechanistic Insight from Computational Molecular Descriptors. Mol. Pharmaceutics 2006, 3, 745– 755,  DOI: 10.1021/mp050096+
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        148
        Chemical Substituent Effect on Pyridine Permeability and Mechanistic Insight from Computational Molecular Descriptors
        Chen, I-Jen; Taneja, Rajneesh; Yin, Daxu; Seo, Paul R.; Young, David; MacKerell, Alexander D., Jr.; Polli, James E.
        Molecular Pharmaceutics (2006), 3 (6), 745-755CODEN: MPOHBP; ISSN:1543-8384. (American Chemical Society)
        The objective was (1) to evaluate the chem. substituent effect on Caco-2 permeability, using a congeneric series of pyridines, and (2) compare mol. descriptors from a computational chem. approach against mol. descriptors from the Hansch approach for their abilities to explain the chem. substituent effect on pyridine permeability. The passive permeability of parent pyridine and 14 monosubstituted pyridines were measured across Caco-2 monolayers. Computational chem. anal. was used to obtain the following mol. descriptions: solvation free energies, solvent accessible surface area, polar surface area, and cavitation energy. Results indicate that the parent pyridine was highly permeable and that chem. substitution was able to reduce pyridine permeability almost 20-fold. The substituent effect on permeability provided the following rank order: 3-COO- < 4-NH2 < 3-CONH2 < 3-Cl < 3-CHO < 3-OH < 3-CH2OH < 3-C6H5 < 3-NH2 < 3-CH2C6H5 < 3-C2H5 < 3-H < 3-CH3 < 3-F < 4-C6H5. This substituent effect was better explained via mol. descriptors from the computational chem. approach than explained by classic descriptors from Hansch. Computational descriptors indicate that aq. desolvation, but not membrane partitioning per se, dictated substituent effect on permeability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtVSrurrO&md5=9886378e912a5cac3d6c66d8f1c2c09e
      148. 148
        Jiang, Z.; Reilly, J.; Everatt, B.; Briard, E. A Rapid Vesicle Electrokinetic Chromatography Method for the in Vitro Prediction of Non-Specific Binding for Potential PET Ligands. J. Pharm. Biomed. Anal. 2011, 54, 722– 729,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpba.2010.11.004
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        149
        A rapid vesicle electrokinetic chromatography method for the in vitro prediction of non-specific binding for potential PET ligands
        Jiang, Zhengjin; Reilly, John; Everatt, Brian; Briard, Emmanuelle
        Journal of Pharmaceutical and Biomedical Analysis (2011), 54 (4), 722-729CODEN: JPBADA; ISSN:0731-7085. (Elsevier B.V.)
        High non-specific binding (NSB) is one of the most common reasons for candidate failure in potential positron emission tomog. (PET) radiotracer development. It is of interest to develop high throughput in vitro methods for predicting non-specific binding prior to radiolabeling, which would help guide radiotracer candidate selection and assist decision making in new radiotracer discovery. We evaluated several electrokinetic chromatog. (EKC) systems to help identify PET ligands with low non-specific binding characteristics by mimicking the ligand-brain tissue interaction. The measured retention factors of tracers in clin. use or terminated candidates within AOT vesicle EKC systems were compared with literature in vitro or in vivo NSB data. We conclude that there is a statistical correlation between the chromatog. retention parameters of tested drugs and their NSB. The AOT vesicle EKC method can provide NSB in vitro trend anal. for a large no. of drug candidates early in the novel radiotracer discovery process with minimal resources.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsF2mtrrO&md5=dd95312fc52995ed2233f2d9ccf7012a

      150. 150
        Linclau, B.; Wang, Z.; Compain, G.; Paumelle, V.; Fontenelle, C. Q.; Wells, N.; Weymouth-Wilson, A.         151
        Investigating the Influence of (Deoxy)fluorination on the Lipophilicity of Non-UV-Active Fluorinated Alkanols and Carbohydrates by a New log P Determination Method
        Linclau, Bruno; Wang, Zhong; Compain, Guillaume; Paumelle, Vincent; Fontenelle, Clement Q.; Wells, Neil; Weymouth-Wilson, Alex
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (2), 674-678CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Property tuning by fluorination is very effective for a no. of purposes, and currently increasingly investigated for aliph. compds. An important application is lipophilicity (log P) modulation. However, the detn. of log P is cumbersome for non-UV-active compds. A new variation of the shake-flask log P detn. method is presented, enabling the measurement of log P for fluorinated compds. with or without UV activity regardless of whether they are hydrophilic or lipophilic. No calibration curves or measurements of compd. masses/aliquot vols. are required. With this method, the influence of fluorination on the lipophilicity of fluorinated aliph. alcs. was detd., and the log P values of fluorinated carbohydrates were measured. Interesting trends and changes, for example, for the dependence on relative stereochem., are reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVOlt7vL&md5=0c6da1c4c979d4275ed961275ca9fcd9
      151. 151
        Avdeef, A. Physicochemical Profiling (Solubility, Permeability and Charge State). Curr. Top. Med. Chem. 2001, 1, 277– 351,  DOI: 10.2174/1568026013395100
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        152
        Physicochemical profiling (solubility, permeability and charge state)
        Avdeef, Alex
        Current Topics in Medicinal Chemistry (Hilversum, Netherlands) (2001), 1 (4), 277-351CODEN: CTMCCL; ISSN:1568-0266. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        A review. About 30% of drug candidate mols. are rejected due to pharmacokinetic-related failures. When poor pharmaceutical properties are discovered in development, the costs of bringing a potent but poorly absorbable mol. to a product stage by "formulation" can become very high. Fast and reliable in vitro prediction strategies are needed to filter out problematic mols. at the earliest stages of discovery. This review will consider recent developments in physicochem. profiling used to identify candidate mols. with phys. properties related to good oral absorption. Poor soly. and poor permeability account for many PK failures. FDA's Biopharmaceutics Classification System (BCS) is an attempt to rationalize the crit. components related to oral absorption. The core idea in the BCS is an in vitro transport model, centrally embracing permeability and soly., with qualifications related to pH and dissoln. The objective of the BCS is to predict in vivo performance of drug products from in vitro measurements of permeability and soly. In principle, the framework of the BCS could serve the interests of the earliest stages of discovery research. The BCS can be rationalized by considering Fick's first law, applied to membranes. When mols. are introduced on one side of a lipid membrane barrier (e.g., epithelial cell wall) and no such mols. are on the other side, passive diffusion will drive the mols. across the membrane. When certain simplifying assumptions are made, the flux equation in Fick's law reduces simply to a product of permeability and soly. Many other measurable properties are closely related to permeability and soly. Permeability (Pe) is a kinetic parameter related to lipophilicity (as indicated by the partition and distribution coeffs., log P and log D). Retention (R) of lipophilic mols. by the membrane (which is related to lipophilicity and may predict. PK vols. of distribution) influences the characterization of permeability. Furthermore, strong drug interactions with serum proteins can influence permeability. The unstirred water layer on both sides of the membrane barrier can impose limits on permeability. Soly. (S) is a thermodn. parameter, and is closely related to dissoln., a kinetic parameter. The unstirred water layer on the surfaces of suspended solids imposes limits on dissoln. Bile acids affect both soly. and dissoln., by a micellization effect. For ionizable mols., pH plays a crucial role. The charge state that a mol. exhibits at a particular pH is characterized by the ionization const. (pKa) of the mol. Buffers effect pH gradients in the unstirred water layers, which can dramatically affect both permeability and dissoln. of ionizable mols. In this review, we will focus on the emerging instrumental methods for the measurement of the physicochem. parameters Pe, S, pKa, R, log P, and log D (and their pH-profiles). These physicochem. profiles can be valuable tools for the medicinal chemists, aiding in the prediction of in vivo oral absorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXms1Khs7o%253D&md5=df94226deaa13e5ade1caec003ae6733
      152. 152
        Vose, C. W.; Ings, R. M. Drug Metabolism. In The Handbook of Medicinal Chemistry: Principles and Practice; Davis, A., Ward, S. E., Eds.; The Royal Society of Chemistry: Cambridge, U.K., 2015; pp 184– 207.
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      153. 153
        Li, F.; Lu, J.; Ma, X. Profiling the Reactive Metabolites of Xenobiotics Using Metabolomic Technologies. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 2011, 24, 744– 751,  DOI: 10.1021/tx200033v
        [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      154. 154
        Peterlin Masic, L. Role of Cyclic Tertiary Amine Bioactivation to Reactive Iminium Species: Structure Toxicity Relationship. Curr. Drug Metab. 2011, 12, 35– 50,  DOI: 10.2174/138920011794520044
        [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar

      155. 155
        Silverman, R. B. The Organic Chemistry of Enzyme-Catalyzed Reactions; Academic Press: San Diego, CA, 2002; pp 193– 219.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      156. 156
        Cobas, C.; Dominguez, S.; Larin, N.; Iglesias, I.; Geada, C.; Seoane, F.; Sordo, M.; Monje, P.; Fraga, S.; Cobas, R.; Peng, C.; Garcia, J. A.; Goebel, M.; Vaz, E. Mestrenova, v6.1.1–6384; Mestrelab Research: Santiago de Compostela, 2010.

      157. 157
        Reindl, W.; Graber, M.; Strebhardt, K.; Berg, T. Development of High-Throughput Assays Based on Fluorescence Polarization for Inhibitors of the polo-Box Domains of Polo-like Kinases 2 and 3. Anal. Biochem. 2009, 395, 189– 194,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ab.2009.08.031
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
